channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Updates: Turkey Agrees to Allow Sweden and Finland to Join NATO
item.description: NATO will formally invite Finland and Sweden to join the alliance on Wednesday after Turkey lifted its veto on their membership, the secretary-general said Tuesday evening.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Colombia Panel’s Report Is a Step Toward Mending a Civil War’s Scars
item.description: A special truth commission criticized Colombia’s security forces and the United States for their role in a half-century conflict that left at least 450,000 people dead.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Federico Rios Escobar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tattered Colombian flag flying over a rebel base in 2018.

item.title: On Front Lines, Communication Breakdowns Prove Costly for Ukraine
item.description: The Ukrainian Army has tried to modernize, but still falls short in coordination among units, so they often fight independently of one another — with sometimes deadly results.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian frontline position near the village of Vilne Pole in the Donetsk region.

item.title: In Russia Crisis, India Tries to Balance Geopolitics and Economics
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who attended the G7 meeting, is also trying to position India as the voice of poorer nations, arguing that sanctions hurt developing countries the most.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India speaking with President Joe Biden, at the G7 Summit in Germany, on Monday.

item.title: ‘I Was Flying Headfirst’: A Shopping Trip Shattered by a Missile
item.description: Survivors of the Russian strike that hit a busy mall in central Ukraine, killing at least 18, described the moment that tore their lives apart.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: As emergency workers combed through the rubble of the mall in Kremenchuk, Ukraine, on Tuesday morning, the city’s mayor declared three days of mourning.

item.title: 101-Year-Old Ex-Guard at Nazi Camp Is Convicted by German Court
item.description: The man, identified only as Josef S. because of German privacy laws, was sentenced to five years in prison after being found guilty of being an accessory to more than 3,500 murders.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The former concentration camp guard identified as Josef S., right, in court. His lawyer said he would fight any attempt to make him serve prison time.

item.title: Scotland’s Leader Calls for Independence Vote, Challenging Judges to Stop It
item.description: First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced a plan for a referendum on Scottish independence next year, but will have to overcome judges in London and opposition from Boris Johnson.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Supreme Court of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: First Minister Nicola Sturgeon of Scotland arriving in the Scottish Parliament in Edinburgh on Tuesday to speak about her plan for a new referendum on independence.

item.title: Marked by the Paris Attacks, and Now Defending Those Accused of Them
item.description: Half the lawyers speaking for the 20 men charged with involvement in the 2015 massacre belong to a young generation in France scarred by a spate of terrorist acts.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Barriers outside the Palais de Justice in Paris this month during the trial over the November 2015 attacks.

item.title: Lost and Found: USB Sticks with Data on 460,000 People
item.description: The plight of a technician tasked with transferring a city’s worth of personal data is a lesson in the risks of combining small, important objects with a night out drinking.
item.dc:creator: Makiko Inoue and Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Takuya Yoshino/The Yomiuri Shimbun, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The city of Amagasaki, Japan, in 2018.

item.title: Mohammed Zubair, Indian Journalist and Modi Critic, Arrested
item.description: Mohammed Zubair, the co-founder of the fact-checking website Alt News and a critic of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, was held after a complaint from an anonymous Twitter user.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Journalists and activists said the detention of Mohammed Zubair was jarring because Prime Minister Narendra Modi had joined leaders at the G7 summit in Germany in promoting press freedom.

item.title: At a Boarding School in Ukraine, Displaced Children Long for Home
item.description: Many left their parents behind when they were evacuated from the country’s east. Now they wrestle with the trauma of a conflict that has consumed much of their young lives.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children watching a movie at a boarding school in Lviv, Ukraine, this month. They were evacuated with some of their teachers from their home city in the east, some 800 miles away.

item.title: At Least 51 Inmates Die in Prison Riot and Fire in Colombia
item.description: The director of the country’s prison system said that inmates had set fire to mattresses, and the blaze spread out of control.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Iñigo Alexander
item.media:description: Jail officials and security forces outside the Tuluá prison after a deadly riot on Tuesday.

item.title: At NATO Summit in Madrid, Debates Underneath the Unity
item.description: The alliance is supporting Ukraine’s defense against Russia with money and arms, but its summit in Madrid this week will involve some difficult talks, including about where to put troops.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: A joint German and Lithuanian NATO military exercise in Rukla, Lithuania, earlier this year. The alliance’s Baltic members want more troops stationed close by.

item.title: U.S. Urges New Tactic to Curb Putin’s War Machine and Lower Fuel Prices
item.description: Group of 7 leaders meeting in Germany were receptive to a Biden administration plan to cap the price of Russian oil in world markets, limiting Kremlin revenue.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden with other G7 leaders in Germany on Monday.

item.title: Abroad, Jacinda Ardern Is a Star. At Home, She’s Losing Her Shine.
item.description: New problems in New Zealand like inflation and gang violence and old problems like unaffordable housing have sent her polling numbers to new lows as an election looms next year.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand, center left, delivered the commencement address at Harvard last month.

item.title: Deborah James, British Cancer Campaigner and Podcaster, Dies at 40
item.description: Ms. James, a podcaster and writer, had chronicled her struggle with an incurable bowel tumor with candor and vivacity after the illness was diagnosed more than five years ago.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Deborah James at the Best Heroes Awards in London, England, in 2019.

item.title: As Monkeypox Spreads, U.S. Plans a Vaccination Campaign
item.description: States will be given vaccine doses from the federal stockpile, but supplies of the safest type are limited.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Hiram Durán for The New York Times
item.media:description: Men waited to register for monkeypox vaccinations outside the Chelsea Sexual Health Clinic in Manhattan last week.

item.title: In Blow to Putin, Turkey Won’t Bar Sweden and Finland From NATO
item.description: The change was a victory for President Biden and a setback to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who had justified the Ukraine invasion as a warning against NATO’s expansion.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, Valerie Hopkins, Anton Troianovski and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, center, after the agreement was announced in Madrid on Tuesday.

item.title: Turkey Clears the Way for Finland and Sweden to Join NATO
item.description: The historic deal underscored how the war in Ukraine has backfired for Russia, which has tried to weaken the Atlantic alliance.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: Leaders of NATO, Turkey, Sweden, and Finland after meetings in Madrid on Tuesday, on their way to sign an agreement that clears the way for Finland and Sweden to pursue NATO membership.

item.title: To Counter Putin, Biden Tries to Assemble an Upside-Down Cartel
item.description: President Biden led his Group of 7 counterparts to agree on a plan that would cap the price of Russian oil, a daunting goal that risks the Kremlin restricting supply even further.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: During this week’s meeting of the Group of 7 nations in Germany, President Biden agreed with fellow leaders to seek temporary caps on the price of Russian oil.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: New Jan. 6 Revelations
item.description: Donald Trump tried to loosen security before the riot, a former aide testified.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Cassidy Hutchinson, a former aide to President Donald J. Trump’s final chief of staff, during the hearing on Capitol Hill on Tuesday.

item.title: Matteo Berrettini exits Wimbledon after testing positive for the coronavirus.
item.description: Mr. Berrettini was seeded No. 8 in the tournament, but he was not the first player to withdraw for virus reasons.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:description: Matteo Berrettini of Italy was practicing at the Wimbledon tennis courts on Friday.

item.title: Thieves Hit TEFAF Art Fair in Daylight Heist
item.description: A gang used a sledgehammer to smash open a display case and make off with jewelry at the renowned Dutch art fair, as dealers looked on, aghast.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: TEFAF (The European Fine Art Fair Stichting)
item.media:description: Visitors standing outside the TEFAF Maastricht international art and antiques fair after it was evacuated following a jewel heist on Tuesday.

item.title: ‘This Is Our 1937 moment,’ U.K.’s New Army Chief Says of War in Ukraine
item.description: Gen. Patrick Sanders, alluding to Western Europe’s failure to confront Nazi Germany, said that Britain must not allow Russia’s military action to expand into NATO territory.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Gen. Patrick Sanders, Britain’s army chief, in 2018.

item.title: Colombia’s Truth Commission Is Highly Critical of U.S. Policy
item.description: Its report estimates that 450,000 people were killed in the decades-long internal conflict — more than twice the number previously thought.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Federico Rios Escobar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tattered Colombian flag flying over a rebel base in 2018.

item.title: China Halves Covid Quarantine Time for International Arrivals
item.description: The time will be cut to seven days in a facility, followed by three days of home isolation.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Travelers waiting to be taken to quarantine locations from the Beijing International Airport this month.

item.title: Unexpected Losses
item.description: The governor’s race in Oregon shows how Democrats could be in trouble in November.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s unpopularity is only one of his party’s problems this year.

item.title: G7 Leaders Pledge $4.5 Billion for Food Security Amid Ukraine War
item.description: The planned commitment, more than half of it from the U.S., reflects worldwide alarm at shortages in wheat and sunflower oil caused by Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden with President Emmanuel Macron of France at the Group of 7 summit in Germany on Monday.

item.title: A Cap on the Price of Russian Oil Comes With Many Questions
item.description: The idea is to limit how much Russia can earn from the oil it sells while still keeping markets well supplied.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:description: Oil tanks at a petroleum depot in Vladivostok, Russia, this month.

item.title: The NATO summit in Madrid could see fissures and debate beneath a semblance of unity.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: A joint German and Lithuanian NATO military exercise in Rukla, Lithuania, earlier this year. The alliance’s Baltic members want more troops stationed close by.

item.title: When Brazil Banned Abortion Pills, Women Turned to Drug Traffickers
item.description: With Roe v. Wade overturned, states banning abortion are looking to prevent the distribution of abortion medication. Brazil shows the possible consequences.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: The pharmacy of the university hospital in Recife. Doctors in the hospital have taken many extraneous steps when using the drug “because of the intense paranoia.”

item.title: NATO says it will significantly increase troops assigned to its eastern flank.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine speaking by video link to G7 leaders in Germany on Monday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A growing global food crisis.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Some bakeries in Lebanon have been forced to close because wheat mills are lacking grain.

item.title: After Russian Mall Airstrike, Shocked Ukrainians Grapple With Destruction
item.description: “The worst thing is that this is a shopping mall,” said a town official. “Any of us could have been here.”
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Rescue workers at a site of a shopping mall hit by a Russian missile strike on Monday, in Kremenchuk, Ukraine.

item.title: Lithuania Blames Russia for Cyberattacks
item.description: Hackers have struck dozens of Lithuanian government and private organizations, according to a Lithuanian official.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Cargo trains running from Lithuania to the Russian enclave Kaliningrad near the border railway station in Kybartai, 124 miles west of Vilnius, Lithuania, on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: G7 Leaders Meet in Germany
item.description: Also, Russia defaults on its debt and New Zealand’s prime minister loses support at home.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy appeared on a screen to update G7 leaders on the Russia-Ukraine war during the G7 Summit in the Bavarian Alps, Germany, on Monday.

item.title: Alameda County, Calif., Drops Indoor Mask Mandate After 3 Weeks
item.description: Daily coronavirus case rates in the county are falling, and while the number of residents hospitalized remains high, daily new admissions have stabilized, health officials said.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri and Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: A restaurant in Berkeley, Calif., last year. The mask mandate in Alameda County, which is home to 1.6 million people in the eastern Bay Area, was lifted on Saturday.

item.title: Leonardo Del Vecchio Dies at 87; Transformed Eyeglass Industry
item.description: He merged eyewear with fashion, turning a quotidian necessity into high style. He rose from poverty to become one of the world’s wealthiest men.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Kandell
item.media:description: Leonardo Del Vecchio in 2017. He turned eyeglasses into fashion statements, becoming one of the world’s wealthiest men.

item.title: Redesign Around Notre-Dame to Keep Tourists Moving and Lower Temperatures
item.description: Plans call for more trees around the famed Paris cathedral, which is being rebuilt after a devastating 2019 fire, and for a cooling system in front of the building.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Studio Alma, via Agence France-Presse/Getty Images
item.media:description: A rendering of Notre-Dame Cathedral Square. A planned redesign includes pedestrian-friendly and shaded areas to help face the rising temperatures in the city.

item.title: Poisonous Gas Leak in Jordan Kills at Least 10 People
item.description: Public security officials said a gas tanker sprung a leak while being transported, and video showed a tanker being dropped as it was moved and emitting a large cloud of yellow smoke.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: The toxic gas explosion in Jordan’s Aqaba port, in a still image from CCTV footage broadcast by Jordan’s public broacaster Al-Mamlaka TV on Monday.

item.title: CRISPR, 10 Years On: Learning to Rewrite the Code of Life
item.description: The gene-editing technology has led to innovations in medicine, evolution and agriculture — and raised profound ethical questions about altering human DNA.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: Brittney Griner’s Trial in Russia Will Begin on Friday
item.description: Ms. Griner, a seven-time W.N.B.A. all-star, has been in custody since February.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, one of the W.N.B.A.'s highest profile stars, arriving at court outside of Moscow on Monday. She has been held by Russian authorities since February.

item.title: A Missile Strike Hits Shopping Center With 1,000 People Inside
item.description: Videos of the site, near the railway station in the central city of Kremenchuk, showed a fire raging as emergency workers frantically attempted to extinguish the flames.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Ivan Nechepurenko, Megan Specia and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: State Emergency Service Of Ukraine, via Reuters
item.media:description: The shopping mall that was hit by a Russian missile strike in Kremenchuk, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: In France, YouTubers Deliver Political News to Young Audiences
item.description: YouTubers in the country are finding success by delivering political content to an audience that tends to shun traditional media.
item.dc:creator: Adèle Cordonnier
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Hugo Travers, right, interviewing the Communist Party leader Fabien Roussel in Paris in February. With a large online following, Mr. Travers is a leading news source for young people in France.

item.title: A Weekend of Airstrikes Adds Anxiety to Even Ukraine’s Safest Cities
item.description: The dozens of the missiles launched by Russian forces into Ukraine over the weekend have raised anxiety in Lviv, even in the relative peace of the country’s northwest.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Employees of the Lviv National Art Gallery sheltered in the space’s basement as air raid sirens sounded on Monday.

item.title: What Cases Could Be Next for the Supreme Court
item.description: Five Republican-appointed justices are ambitious and impatient to change American law.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Protesting for abortion rights in Brooklyn last month.

item.title: Exiled Mayor of Sievierodonetsk Talks of Dire Situation
item.description: Residents of Lysychansk, across the river from a city that fell to Russian control last week, should leave over “the real threat to life and health,” the region’s military governor said.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A plume of smoke rose over Bakhmut, Ukraine, last week as Russian forces try to sever key highways that lead to Lysychansk.

item.title: Documenting India’s Distinctive Birdhouses
item.description: For seven years, a photographer based in Delhi has collected images of ornamental structures known as chabutras. Here are some of his favorites.
item.dc:creator: Nipun Prabhakar
item.media:description: A large birdhouse in the village of Sinugra, in the western state of Gujarat. The structure not only houses birds but also has space to store their grains.

item.title: Europe and the U.S. court India to join efforts to punish Russia.
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India has maintained a neutral stance on the war.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj and Emily Schmall
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, left, with Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany on Monday. The Indian leader was invited to join the G7 summit meeting along with the leaders of four other countries with close ties to Russia.

item.title: U.S. officials say the G7 is close to an agreement on price caps on Russian oil.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: Oil tanks at a petroleum depot in Vladivostok, Russia, this month.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: The end of Roe v. Wade.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protestors clashing outside the Supreme Court on Sunday.

item.title: Colombian Bullfight Stand Collapse Kills at Least 6
item.description: One child was reported dead when a spectator section collapsed at a bullfighting festival, and more than a hundred were reported injured.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Photo by Samuel Antonio Galindo Campos/AFP via Getty Images
item.media:description: An aerial view of the collapsed grandstand in El Espinal, Colombia, on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: The End of Roe
item.description: Plus Russia strikes Kyiv as G7 leaders meet and a Times investigation into China’s surveillance state.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Pro-choice protestors tried to block an anti-abortion protestor outside the Supreme Court in Washington on Saturday.

item.title: G7 Leaders Work to Punish Russia Over Ukraine War
item.description: On the first day of their gathering, Group of 7 leaders moved to increase the economic pressure on Russia, but a missile attack on the Ukrainian capital made clear that Moscow is not backing down.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Group of 7 leaders at a working lunch in the Bavarian Alps on Sunday.

item.title: Missile Strike in Kyiv Rattles Residents After Weeks of Quiet
item.description: The strike on Sunday morning shook many out of the relative sense of security that has prevailed in Ukraine’s capital since the Russians were pushed out of its periphery in early April.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: The site of a Russian missile strike on Kyiv, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Prominent Activist in India Arrested Over Crusade Against Modi in Deadly Riots
item.description: Teesta Setalvad was detained by an antiterrorism squad to face charges of fabricating evidence against Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Manpreet Romana for The New York Times
item.media:description: Teesta Setalvad, center, in 2015 with women who lost relatives in sectarian riots that shook Gujarat, India, in 2002.

item.title: Past G7 summits have produced some memorable photos.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: G7 leaders last year in Britain.

item.title: Ukraine War’s Latest Victim? The Fight Against Climate Change.
item.description: As leaders of the Group of 7 gather in Germany, the scramble to replace Russian fossil fuels is raising concerns that hard-won climate targets will be missed.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: Steam rising from the cooling towers of a lignite-fired power plant in Neurath, Germany.
